data.title: Gary Cooper never recovered from his life-threatening tumour – symptoms
data.meta_description: GARY COOPER is remembered as the all-American movie cowboy, famed for Westerns such as High Noon (1952), but the film star died when cancer took hold.
data.text:
Hollywood icon Gary Cooper never recovered from his life-threatening tumour – symptoms

GARY COOPER is remembered as the all-American movie cowboy, famed for Westerns such as High Noon (1952), but the film star died when cancer took hold.

By Chanel Georgina, Senior Reporter

Link copied Bookmark

Prostate cancer: Doctor outlines symptoms you might experience

A notable Hollywood icon, Gary Cooper starred in classics such as Mr Deeds Goes To Town (1936), Sergeant York (1941), and The Pride Of The Yankees (1942). Dying from cancer, aged 60, which type of tumour took his life? Cooper's death was not attributed to one cause, as the two-time Oscar winner had two tumours – one in his prostate and another in his colon. Shortly before his death on May 13, 1961, Cooper received an Academy Honorary Award for his career achievements.

Throughout his 28-year marriage to Veronica Balfe, he gained a reputation as a womaniser.

Cooper had multiple affairs, even after having a child – Maria – with his wife.

In fact, Cooper was involved in a number of romantic scandals; most of his entanglements were with his film co-stars.

While chronically unfaithful, Balfe stood by her husband's side till the very end.

READ MORE: Covid cases ‘starting to go up again’ warns expert – top five symptoms in current cases

Prostate cancer

A tumour in the prostate can grow ever so slowly that there may be no signs in the earliest stages of disease, the NHS says.

When the tumour is "large enough" to affect the urethra – the tube that carries urine from the bladder out of the tip of the penis – symptoms can begin to emerge.

Noticeable symptoms of prostate cancer can include:

An increased need to pee

Straining while you pee

A feeling that your bladder has not fully emptied.

These symptoms can replicate those caused by prostate enlargement, which is a normal part of ageing.

However, if you don't get the symptoms checked out, if there is a cancerous tumour, it is then allowed more time to grow and spread.

Cancer Research UK notes that when cancer spreads from the prostate to elsewhere in the body, it is known as "advanced prostate cancer".

The tumour can spread to numerous body parts, such as the lymph nodes, the liver, or lungs.

Or, like it did with Cooper, it can spread to other organs, including the colon.

READ MORE: Covid cases ‘starting to go up again’ warns expert – top five symptoms in current cases

Stage three and stage four prostate cancer are defined by a tumour that has spread outside of the prostate.

A person's chance of survival depends on the stage of cancer when it was diagnosed.

Treatments can involve radiotherapy, chemotherapy, surgery, and hormone therapy.

For some people, medical professionals will inform them that their cancer can not be cured.

As such, treatment is then used to help prevent the cancer from spreading elsewhere in the body.

Treatment is also utilised to help relieve symptoms of the life-threatening tumour.

Advanced prostate cancer is likely to cause physical changes in your body, such as:

Changes to the way your bowel and bladder work

Feeling very tired and lacking in energy a lot of the time

Changes can affect your relationships and sex life.

Gary Cooper starred in Distant Drums, which shows on Film4, on Wednesday, September 14 at 2.50pm.
